p: There is considerable spatio-temporal variation in the modelled climate suitability for B. tabaci MEAM1 in eastern Africa at the inter-annual scale (Supplementary Figs. S2, S3). Despite this variability, there has been a significant trend in climate suitability throughout much of Eastern Africa during the 39 years from 1979 to 2017 (Fig. 6). For each cell there were 38 degrees of freedom. Throughout this period, there has been a slight decrease in climate suitability for B. tabaci in lower-lying coastal regions (Fig. 6a), though apart from an area in Mozambique, only a few isolated areas appear to have experienced a statistically significant decrease in suitability (Fig. 6c). Conversely, there has been an increase in suitability throughout a large portion of the area, which is most pronounced in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi, and western parts of Tanzania and Kenya (Fig. 6a,b). These trends are apparent in both the EI and the GI A results against a backdrop of interannual variation (Fig. 7a,b). Exploring the temporal data in more detail for selected locations reveals that most of the increase in suitability is due to increasing temperature suitability (Fig. 7c) and decreases in the EI are due to decreasing soil moisture suitability and drought stress (Fig. 7d). At Luweero and Mwanza, in the centre of the cassava disease epidemic zone, climatic conditions for both temperature and soil moisture improved through this period.
